verses.text: Not long after this the king sent an old man of Athens to compel the Jews to depart from the laws of \add their\add* fathers, and not to live after the laws of God:

and to pollute also the temple in Jerusalem, and to call \add it the temple\add* of Jupiter Olympius; and that in Garizim, of Jupiter the Defender of strangers, as they did desire that dwelt in the place.
The coming in of \add this\add* mischief was sore and grievous to the people:

for the temple was filled with riot and revelling by the Gentiles, who dallied with harlots, and had to do with women within the circuit of the holy \add places\add*, and besides that, brought in \add things\add* that were not lawful.
The altar also was filled with profane \add things\add*, which the law forbiddeth.
Neither was it \add lawful for a man\add* to keep sabbath days or ancient feasts, or to profess \add himself\add* at all to be a Jew.

And in the day of the king’s birth every month they were brought by bitter constraint to eat of the sacrifices; and when the feast of Bacchus was kept, the Jews were compelled to go in procession to Bacchus, carrying ivy.

Moreover there went out a decree to the neighbour cities of the heathen, by the suggestion of Ptolemee, against the Jews, that \add they\add* should observe the same fashions, and be partakers of \add their\add* sacrifices:
and whoso would not conform themselves to the \add manners\add* of the Gentiles should be put to death. Then might \add a man\add* have seen the present misery.

For there were two women brought, who had circumcised their children; whom when they had openly led round about the city, the babes hanging at their breasts, they cast them down headlong from the wall.

And others, that had run together into caves near by, to keep the sabbath day secretly, being discovered to Philip, were \add all\add* burnt together, because \add they\add* made a conscience to help themselves for the honour of the most sacred day.

Now I beseech those that read this book, that \add they\add* be not discouraged for \add these\add* calamities, but that \add they\add* judge \add those\add* punishments not to be for destruction, but for a chastening of our nation.
For it is a token of \add his\add* great goodness, when wicked doers are not suffered \add any\add* long time, but forthwith punished.
For not as with other nations, \add whom\add* the Lord patiently forbeareth to punish, till they be come to the fulness of \add their\add* sins, so dealeth he with us,
lest that, being come to the height of sin, afterwards he should take vengeance of us.
\add And\add* therefore he never withdraweth his mercy from us: and though he punish with adversity, \add yet\add* doth he never forsake his people.
But let this that we have spoken be for a warning unto us. And \add now\add* will \add we\add* come to the declaring \add of the matter\add* in few \add words\add*.
Eleazar, one of the principal scribes, an aged man, and of a well favoured countenance, was constrained to open his mouth, and to eat swine’s flesh.
But he, choosing rather to die gloriously, than to live \add stained\add* with \add such\add* an abomination, spit \add it\add* forth, and came of his own accord to the torment,
as it behoved \add them\add* to come, that are resolute to stand out \add against such things\add*, as \add are\add* not lawful for love of life to be tasted.

But they that had the charge of \add that\add* wicked feast, for the old acquaintance \add they\add* had with the man, taking him aside, besought \add him\add* to bring flesh of his own provision, such as \add was\add* lawful for him to use, and make as if he did eat of the flesh taken from the sacrifice commanded by the king;
that in so doing he might be delivered from death, and for the old friendship with them find favour.

But he began to consider discreetly, and as became \add his\add* age, and the excellency of \add his\add* ancient years, and the honour of \add his\add* gray head, whereunto he was come, and \add his\add* most honest education from a child, or rather the holy law made and given by God: therefore he answered accordingly, and willed \add them\add* straightways to send \add him\add* to the grave.

For it becometh not our age, \add said he, in any wise\add* to dissemble, whereby many young \add persons\add* might think that Eleazar, \add being\add* fourscore years old and ten, were \add now\add* gone to a strange religion;

and \add so\add* they through mine hypocrisy, and \add desire\add* to live a little \add time\add* and a moment \add longer\add*, should be deceived by me, and I get a stain to \add mine\add* old age, and make it abominable.
For though for the present \add time\add* I should be delivered from the punishment of men: yet should I not escape the hand of the Almighty, neither alive, nor dead.
Wherefore now, manfully changing \add this\add* life, I will shew myself such a one as \add mine\add* age requireth,

and leave a notable example to \add such as be\add* young to die willingly and courageously for the honourable and holy laws. And when he had said these \add words\add*, immediately he went to the torment:
they that led \add him\add* changing the good will they bare him a little before into hatred, because the foresaid speeches proceeded, as they thought, from a desperate mind.

But when he was ready to die with stripes, he groaned, and said, It is manifest unto the Lord, that hath the holy knowledge, that whereas I might have been delivered from death, I \add now\add* endure sore pains in body by being beaten: but in soul am well content to suffer these \add things\add*, because I fear him.
And thus this \add man\add* died, leaving his death for an example of a noble courage, and a memorial of virtue, not only unto young \add men\add*, but unto all \add his\add* nation.
